block.p: Refugees' Stories Back Massacre Reports in Congo Hutu refugees' tales have given added force to concerns that the forces of Laurent Kabila, who is now the President, may have massacred people in Congo, the former Zaire, well after they had taken the upper hand in the civil war that led to Mr. Kabila taking power.

Polish Leader Ponders Strategy After the surprise victory of the Solidarity coalition in Poland's elections, Marian Krzaklewski, the party leader, has set about clarifying his intentions and building a Government. He has said that he would prefer to run his party's parliamentary caucus than to be made Prime Minister. Many think that he would prefer to wait three years and run against President Aleksander Kwasniewski, a former Communist.

Clinton Addresses the U.N. President Clinton told the United Nations General Assembly that he is asking the Senate to ratify the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. In all, 146 nations have signed the treaty, but of the 44 countries that must ratify it, only Japan has done so. Mr. Clinton also urged the creation of a permanent international court by the end of the century to prosecute ''the most serious violations of humanitarian law.''

Pakistan Leader Courts India Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan invited India to open negotiations on a mutual ''nonaggression pact.'' After his speech to the United Nations General Assembly, he dined with President Clinton and Prime Minister I. K. Gujral of India.

Gore Presses Russia on Bill Vice President Al Gore said his first topic in talks with Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin of Russia in the town of Bor was the United States's objection to a new bill designed to protect the Russian Orthodox Church against competition from other Christian faiths.

Challenge to Serb Socialists Partial returns in the Serbian presidential and parliamentary elections forecast the need for a second round of voting for the presidency, a setback for the Socialist alliance of Yugoslavia's President, Slobodan Milosevic. The hard-line nationalist Radical Prty was close behind the Socialists, and the returns indicated that no party would win an outright parliamentary majority. A boycott by opposition parties hoping that an inadequate turnout would invalidate the elections failed.

South African Lawsuit Dropped South Africa's National Party dropped its lawsuit against the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission. The party relented after receiving formal apologies from two of the commission's leaders for remarks they made about the credibility of the testimony of former President F. W. de Klerk in May. Mr. de Klerk had said his party, which ruled South Africa during apartheid, had never authorized killings to combat anti-apartheid forces.

Thalidomide May Be Used To Treat Several Diseases Thalidomide, the drug whose use in the 1960's produced thousands of deformed babies, is on the verge of receiving approval from the Food and Drug Administration for use in leprosy patients, nearly four decades after the agency rejected it for use in the United States. But experts expect doctors to begin prescribing it quickly for ''off-label'' uses. Thalidomide has been experiencing a revival of sorts, and scientists are experimenting with it for everything from AIDS to brain cancer and other autoimmune diseases.

Clinton Defends Fund-Raising President Clinton said he was confident neither he nor his campaign broke ''the letter of the law'' in fund-raising. But the chairman of the Senate committee investigating the question says everything he has found points toward the need for an independent counsel.

Lee Brown in a Mayor's Race Lee P. Brown, the former New York City police commissioner, is the current front-runner in this fall's race for Mayor in Houston, in which victory would make him the first black mayor in the city's history.

F.D.A. Bill Nears Vote A bill to speed review for many medical devices and drugs is expected to come to a vote on the Senate floor this week. Senator Edward M. Kennedy has filibustered the legislation, which outlines the authority given to the Food and Drug Administration, winning concessions for causes he calls ''pro-consumer.''

Rise Seen in Tobacco Profits Tobacco industry profits could soar as much as $123 billion under terms of a legal settlement proposed in June by 40 state attorneys general and cigarette makers, according to an analysis by the Federal Trade Commission.

Marv Albert Trial Begins Marv Albert, the NBC sportscaster, pleaded not guilty to charges of sodomy and assault against a 42-year-old Virginia woman in a hotel room in Arlington last February as his trial began in state court.

Crew Rejects School's Plan To Preserve Teaching Job A group of parents who raised more than $46,000 to preserve a teacher's job and keep class size down at their school were rebuffed by Chancellor Rudy Crew, who said the fund-raising drive was unfair to other schools with large class sizes.

Mayoral Rivals Trade Charges Mayor Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger delved into the past, searching for information that they could use to derail each other's mayoral candidacies. The Mayor accused Ms. Messinger of holding a party in 1979 for an inmate convicted of killing an Attica Prison guard. Ms. Messinger responded by saying Mr. Giuliani tried to dodge the draft in 1969.

Sharpton Wins Round in Court A New York State Supreme Court justice ordered an immediate hearing into the Rev. Al Sharpton's allegation that he was unfairly denied a runoff bid because the vote count following the Democratic mayoral primary on Sept. 9 was riddled with fraud and other irregularities.

Sun Tied to Global Warming Scientists are developing an increasing body of evidence that links solar variations to climate shifts on Earth -- perhaps rivaling human pollution as a factor in global warming.
Doubts on Growth Treatment A large study has cast strong doubt on the increasingly common practice of giving growth hormone injections to short children to help them reach an average height.

Seagram Buys Network Stake Seagram agreed to pay Viacom $1.7 billion for the 50 percent of the cable programming service, USA Network, it does not already own.

China Plans Cautious Opening China's newly elevated economic czar, Zhu Rongji, said he planned to move cautiously in opening up China's market and exposing its sclerotic Government-owned enterprises to foreign competition.

Rights to Java Defended Sun Microsystems said it would not give up ownership of the Java computer language, as Microsoft and other companies have suggested, in order to have it officially certified as an international standard.

A New 'Lolita' Controversy ''Lolita,'' a new film remake of the novel, is about to open across Europe but not in the United States, where major distributors have so far shunned Vladimir Nabokov's disturbing story of an older man's passion for a prepubescent girl.

Troubled Industry of Broadway The New York theater industry is still in decline and beset by rising costs and lagging audiences despite some signs of life, an unusually detailed industry-sponsored study has concluded.
